These tumors include a cancer in immature nerve cells (neuroblastoma), intermediate (benign or cancerous) tumors in the sympathetic nervous system (ganglioneuroblastoma), and benign tumors on a specific type of nerve cell called ganglion cells (ganglioneuroma). People with this condition have a greater than 50% chance of developing at least one type of neuroblastic tumor. The risk of tumor development is highest during infancy. Risk decreases by late childhood. Most tumors develop by ten years of age. Susceptibility to neuroblastoma 3 has been tied to mutations in the ALK gene. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. This means a single copy of the mutated gene is sufficient to cause the disorder.

Summary of Cutis laxa, autosomal recessive, type ib: Autosomal recessive cutis laxa type IB (ARCL1B) is a rare genetic connective tissue disorder. It is characterized by loose skin along with symptoms in other parts of the body. Babies with this disorder may experience fractures during the birth process. They may also have long, thin fingers (arachnodactyly) and flexible joints. Other symptoms include breathing difficulties known as emphysema and cardiopulmonary insufficiency. These cause the lungs and heart to struggle to remove carbon dioxide and supply oxygen to the blood. The condition may also cause fragile blood vessels. These symptoms are all related to changes in the formation of elastic fiber. Elastic fiber is an important component of connective tissue. ARCL1B is caused by mutations in the EFEMP2 gene. As the name suggests, this condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. This means that two copies of the mutated gene are required to cause the disease.

Summary of Pontocerebellar hypoplasia, type 1b: Pontocerebellar hypoplasia type 1B (PCH1B) is an inherited brain disorder. This condition is present at birth. It causes the cerebellum and spinal motor neurons to degrade. Symptoms include muscle weakness and a smaller than average head size. This condition can also cause developmental delays. The age of onset, severity of symptoms, and progression of disease can vary from person to person. This condition is caused by mutations in the EXOSC3 gene. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. This means two copies of the mutated gene are required to cause the disease.

Summary of Myoclonic-atonic epilepsy: Myoclonic-atonic epilepsy (MAE) is a type of epilepsy that starts in early childhood. This condition is characterized by absence and myoclonic seizures. Absence seizures are characterized by a brief loss of consciousness. Myoclonic seizures are characterized by short episodes of involuntary jerking movements in different muscle groups. Patients with MAE often experience delayed development before the onset of seizures. They may also have varying degrees of impaired intellectual development following seizure onset. MAE is caused by mutations in the SLC6A1 gene. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. This means a single copy of the mutated gene is sufficient to cause the disorder. Most cases occur for the first time in a family as the result of a new (de novo) mutation.

Summary of Developmental and epileptic encephalopathy 34: Developmental and epileptic encephalopathy 34 (DEE34) is a rare neurological disorder. It is characterized by the onset of seizures in the first year of life. Seizures are observed after normal early development. The seizures caused by this condition are known as refractory migrating focal seizures. This type of seizure starts in one area of the brain and moves to another. The seizures are resistant to treatment with antiepileptic drugs (refractory). Children with DEE34 experience developmental regression and severe global impairment. This condition is caused by mutations in the SLA12A5 gene. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. This means that two copies of the mutated gene are required to cause the disease.

Summary of Developmental and epileptic encephalopathy 46: Developmental and epileptic encephalopathy 46 (DEE46) is a neurological condition. It is characterized by the onset of difficult-to-treat seizures during infancy or childhood. This condition can also cause global developmental delay and failure to thrive. This means the child doesn't grow and develop as expected. Symptoms may also include low muscle tone (hypotonia), overactive reflexes (hyperreflexia), and intellectual disability. Some children have more severe impairments and may not be able to sit or speak. Others may achieve some developmental milestones. DEE46 is caused by mutations in the GRIN2D gene. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. This means a single copy of the mutated gene is sufficient to cause the disorder. Most cases occur for the first time in a family as the result of a new (de novo) mutation.

Summary of Developmental and epileptic encephalopathy 54: Developmental and epileptic encephalopathy 54 (DEE54) is a neurological condition. It is characterized by the onset of difficult-to-treat seizures during infancy or childhood. The seizures are often initially related to fevers but later occur without fevers. Other symptoms include delayed psychomotor development and intellectual disability. These symptoms impair learning and physical development. Many children with this condition have decreased muscle tone and delayed or absent speech. They may also have difficulty with daily tasks such as feeding. DEE54 is caused by mutations in the HNRNPU gene. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. This means a single copy of the mutated gene is sufficient to cause the disorder. Most cases occur for the first time in a family as the result of a new (de novo) mutation.

Summary of Cohen-gibson syndrome: Cohen-Gibson syndrome (COGIS) is a rare genetic disorder. It is characterized by overgrowth that presents at birth or during early childhood. Children with this condition have a large head, are taller than their peers and have large hands and feet. They may also have advanced bone age, which means that the bones appear older than the childâs actual age. People with COGIS may also have intellectual disability which can range from mild to severe. In addition, they may have a curved spine (scoliosis) or other skeletal differences. Some may also have low muscle tone, trouble walking, and hernias. COGIS is caused by mutations in the EED gene. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. This means a single copy of the mutated gene is sufficient to cause the disorder.

Summary of Spondyloepimetaphyseal dysplasia with joint laxity, type 3: Spondyloepimetaphyseal dysplasia with joint laxity type 3 (SEMDJL3) is a rare genetic disorder. It affects the bones and joints. People with SEMDJL3 are born with dislocations of the hips and knees. Symptoms may also include very loose joints, a curved spine (scoliosis), and slender bones in the hands and feet. SEMDJL3 can cause delayed bone growth and poorly developed wrist and ankle bones. This condition is caused by a change in the EXOC6B gene. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. This means that two copies of the mutated gene are required to cause the disease.

Summary of Autosomal recessive Robinow syndrome: Autosomal recessive Robinow syndrome (RRS) is a genetic disorder that affects a person's growth and appearance. This condition presents at birth or in early childhood. It can cause short stature and short limbs. It may also cause segmentation defects which result in problems with the vertebrae and ribs. RSS may also affect features of a person's head, neck, and external genitalia.

Summary of Mucocutaneous venous malformations: Mucocutaneous venous malformations (VMCMs) are hereditary vascular malformations. They are characterized by abnormal blood vessel formation known as venous lesions. Venous lesions cause small, bluish-purple spots to develop. They occur on the skin or mucous membranes.

Summary of Episodic ataxia type 1: Episodic ataxia type 1 (EA1) is a form of hereditary episodic ataxia. It is characterized by short periods of uncoordinated movement. This condition can also cause muscle stiffness known as neuromyotoni. It also causes muscle twitching between episodes known as continuous interictal myokymia.

Summary of Congenital cataracts-facial dysmorphism-neuropathy syndrome: Congenital cataracts-facial dysmorphism-neuropathy (CCFDN) syndrome is a complex developmental disorder. It has autosomal recessive inheritance. That means both parents must pass along a copy of the gene that causes this condition. CCFDN is characterized by congenital cataracts (cloudy areas in the lens of the eye present at birth). It also causes abnormalities of the face, and neuropathy. Nerve disorders causing muscle weakness, numbness, and pain are known as neuropathy.

Summary of Oculocutaneous albinism type 4: Oculocutaneous albinism type 4 is a condition that affects the color of a person's skin, hair, and eyes. This condition can cause the skin and hair to have less color than usual. It can also cause changes that affect the eyes. These changes may include misrouting of the optic nerves where they cross at the base of the brain.

Summary of Microcephalic osteodysplastic dysplasia, Saul-Wilson type: Microcephalic osteodysplastic dysplasia, Saul-Wilson type, is a rare genetic disorder. It affects bone growth and development. This condition can be characterized by distinct facial features and short stature. Facial features may include a prominent forehead with a dent in the middle where the skull bones meet. Features also include a nose with a narrow base and hooked appearance. Some people may also have large eyes, cataracts (clouding of the lens of the eye). This condition may also cause microcephay (smaller than average head size). Other symptoms may include clubfoot (inward turning of the foot) and brachydactyly (shortening of the fingers and toes).

Summary of ATTRV30M amyloidosis: ATTRV30M amyloidosis is a progressive sensorimotor and autonomic neuropathy. This means it affects the nerves responsible for movement and sensation. It also affects the autonomic nervous system. The autonomic nervous system controls involuntary functions like heart rate and digestion. ATTRV30M typically starts in adulthood and gets more severe over time. It often leads to weight loss and heart problems and may also cause issues with the eyes or kidneys.

Summary of Lissencephaly due to LIS1 mutation: Lissencephaly due to LIS1 mutation is a brain disorder that affects the way the brain develops. It is characterized by posterior isolated lissencephaly. This means the brain has a smooth surface due to incomplete neuronal migration. This is associated with developmental delay and intellectual disability. Symptoms also include epilepsy that usually evolves from West syndrome to Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. Additional symptoms include low muscle tone (hypotonia) and acquired microcephaly (small head). People with this condition may also experience failure to thrive. This means the child doesn't grow or develop as expected. This condition may also cause poor control of the airways, leading to aspiration pneumonia.

Summary of Huntington disease-like 2: Huntington disease-like 2 (HDL2) is a rare and severe neurodegenerative disorder. It shares many of the same symptoms with Huntington Disease (HD). It primarily affects people of African descent. It is characterized by a combination of movement, psychiatric, and cognitive abnormalities. Movement-related symptoms include involuntary, rapid, jerky movements. These are known as chorea and eye movement issues. This condition may also cause symptoms like those seen in Parkinson's disease. Those include slow movement, muscle stiffness, and tremors. Psychiatric symptoms include pronounced feelings of sadness, irritability, and anxiety. Cognitive symptoms may include early cognitive decline. They may also include subcortical-like dementia. This affects a person's ability to think, reason, and remember.

Summary of Congenital stromal corneal dystrophy: Congenital stromal corneal dystrophy (CSCD) is a very rare eye condition that affects the cornea, the clear outer layer of the eye. Corneal lesions develop before birth. Over time, opaque, flaky, or feathery clouding of the corneal stroma (the middle layer of the cornea) occurs. This causes progressive problems with vision. People with CSCD typically experience moderate to severe visual loss.

Summary of Action myoclonus-renal failure syndrome: Action myoclonus-renal failure syndrome is a rare type of epilepsy that is linked to kidney problems. People with this condition have progressive myoclonus epilepsy. This means they experience jerking movements (myoclonus) that get worse over time. people may have a condition called primary glomerular disease, which affects the kidneys. People with this condition may also experience various neurological symptoms. These can include tremors, sudden, involuntary movements known as action myoclonus. This condition can cause a type of seizure that involves convulsions known as tonic-clonic seizures. This condition may also cause loss of coordination (ataxia) and difficulty speaking (dysarthria). Neurological symptoms may appear before, at the same time, or after kidney-related issues. Kidney issues may include high levels of protein in the urine (proteinuria). This condition can also cause nephrotic syndrome. Nephrotic syndrome is a group of symptoms that indicate kidney damage. In some cases, the condition progresses to end-stage renal disease (kidney failure). People with this condition may also experience nerve damage. The damage affects movement and sensation (sensorimotor peripheral neuropathy). It can also cause sensorineural hearing loss. This condition may cause weakening and enlargement of the heart muscle (dilated cardiomyopathy).

Summary of Cutis laxa with severe pulmonary, gastrointestinal and urinary anomalies: Cutis laxa with severe pulmonary, gastrointestinal, and urinary anomalies is a rare genetic connective tissue disorder. This condition is caused by a problem with the elastic tissue in the skin, which leads to saggy and wrinkly skin all over the body. People with this condition often have an early-onset form of emphysema, a lung problem that makes it hard to breathe. The condition can also cause issues in the stomach, intestines, bladder, and kidneys. These problems can include weak spots in the bladder or intestines. It can also cause twisted or stretched parts of the gastrointestinal system. Symptoms may also include swelling of the kidneys. In some cases, the condition can also affect the heart and blood vessels. Typically it causes narrowing of the arteries in the lungs

Summary of Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 4: Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 4 (MEN4) is an extremely rare inherited cancer syndrome. It is characterized by the development of tumors in the parathyroid and anterior pituitary glands. The parathyroid glands are located near the thyroid gland in the neck. Anterior pituitary tumors occur in the pituitary gland, which is located at the base of the brain. Other tumors that may be associated with MEN4 include adrenal gland tumors. Adrenal gland tumors which are located on top of the kidneys, and renal tumors occurring in the kidneys. This condition can also cause tumors that occur in the reproductive organs (ovaries or testes).

Summary of Pelizaeus-Merzbacher-like disease due to GJC2 mutation: Pelizaeus-Merzbacher-like disease due to GJC2 mutation (PLMD1) is a rare genetic neurological disorder. This disease is characterized by a range of symptoms that typically appear at birth or in early childhood. Symptoms include uncontrolled eye movement (nystagmus) and decreased muscle tone (hypotonia). People with this condition also have developmental delays in crawling, standing, or walking. Speech delays and difficulties due to weak muscles (dysarthria) may also occur. Over time, the muscles become stiff and difficult to control (spasticity). This can affect mobility and communication. In some cases, people with PLMD1 may also experience other neurological issues. These include uncoordinated, involuntary, unpredictable, or repetitive movements. The issues related to muscles may eventually lead to difficulties with swallowing. They may also lead to problems with the skeletal system like dislocated hips or a curved spine (scoliosis). In rare cases, people may also develop problems with their hearing and sight. PLMD1 is caused by mutations in the GJC2 gene. This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. This means two copies of the mutated gene are required to cause the disease.

Summary of Early-onset myopathy with fatal cardiomyopathy: Early-onset myopathy with fatal cardiomyopathy is a rare genetic neuromuscular disease. It affects both muscles and the heart. This condition may cause generalized muscle weakness during infancy. This includes weakness in the facial muscles. It can also lead to enlargement of lower limb muscles (pseudohypertrophy). Symptoms also include tightness in the joints called contractures. In childhood, the disease is associated with a rapidly progressive form of dilated cardiomyopathy. Cardiomyopathy is a condition where the heart muscle becomes weak and enlarged. This can lead to abnormal heart rhythms, called arrhythmias. Cardiomyopathy can even lead to sudden cardiac death.

Summary of Microcephaly-capillary malformation syndrome: Microcephaly-capillary malformation syndrome is a rare, genetic disorder that affects the blood vessels. This condition is characterized by severe small head size (microcephaly). The difference in head size is present at birth. It can also cause slow overall growth and abnormal blood vessels on the skin. These are known as diffuse multiple capillary malformations. People with this condition may also have epilepsy with severe seizures. The seizures may be difficult to control. Additional symptoms include significant delays in overall, or "global," development. People may also experience difficulty moving and controlling the limbs (spastic quadriparesis). They may also have smaller than average (hypoplastic) fingers and toes.

Summary of Kyphoscoliotic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome due to FKBP22 deficiency: Kyphoscoliotic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome due to FKBP22 deficiency is a rare subtype of yphoscoliotic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, a genetic connective tissue disorder. It is characterized by hypotonia (low muscle tone) that is present at birth. This condition causes early-onset kyphoscoliosis (curvature of the spine) that may or may not be progressive. This condition can also cause generalized joint hypermobility. Full or partial dislocations, may accompany hypermobility. Dislocations particularly occur in the shoulders, hips, and knees. Other common features include hyperextensible or stretchy skin. The skin bruises easily. Symptoms include aneurysms (bulging or weakened arteries). People with this condition may have brittle bones, and/or blue tint to the whites of the eyes. Symptoms may also include umbilical or inguinal (groin area) hernia. Symptoms may also include umbilical or inguinal (groin area) hernia. Other people have chest deformity, and/or tall, thin body shape known as marfanoid habitus. Some have clubfoot (talipes equinovarus), and vision problems. This subtype of kyphoscoliotic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome can be associated with sensorineural, conductive, or mixed hearing loss that is present at birth. It can also cause thickened skin on the scalp known as follicular hyperkeratosis. It can cause atrophy, or shrinkage, of muscles. Symptoms also include abnormal pouches in the bladder known as bladder diverticula. Genetic testing is necessary to confirm this diagnosis.

Summary of Congenital cataract-hearing loss-severe developmental delay syndrome: Congenital cataract-hearing loss-severe developmental delay syndrome is a rare, genetic condition. It is characterized by clouding of the lens in the eye that is present at birth (congenital cataracts). It also causes a type of hearing loss caused by damage to the inner ear or the nerve that runs from the ear to the brain (sensorineural hearing loss). Symptoms include psychomotor developmental delay. This means people have significant delays in acquiring motor skills and cognitive abilities. This condition can cause severe, generalized muscular hypotonia. Severe, generalized muscular hypotonia is low muscle tone throughout the body. Changes to the central nervous system are also present. These include an underdeveloped brain (cerebellar and cerebral hypoplasia). There may also be reduced myelin covering the nerves in the brain (hypomyelination). Further central nervous system changes include a wider than usual space between the brain and skull (subarachnoid spaces). This accompanies low blood levels of copper and a protein that transports copper called ceruloplasmin. In some cases, involuntary eye movement (nystagmus) and seizures may also be present.

Summary of GM2 gangliosidosis, AB variant: GM2 gangliosidosis, AB variant is a rare, genetic disorder. It causes a gradual decline in neurological function. This is due to a deficiency in a substance called ganglioside activator. Ganglioside activator stimulates the activity of gangliosides. Gangliosides are fat-like substances in cell membranes that play various roles in cell function. When gangliosides donât work correctly, neurological symptoms develop. Infants with condition show progressive weakness. They also have slowing of developmental progress during the first year. Over time, symptoms including difficulty swallowing, seizures, and tightened muscles increase in severity.

Summary of Autosomal recessive severe congenital neutropenia due to G6PC3 deficiency: Autosomal recessive severe congenital neutropenia due to G6PC3 deficiency is a rare genetic disorder. This condition affects the immune system. It makes the body more likely to get serious bacterial infections. This disease is caused by problems in a gene called G6PC3, which is inherited from both parents. People with this condition often have very low levels of neutrophils. Neutrophils are a type of white blood cell. Low levels of neutrophils can make it harder for the body to fight infections. This condition can also cause problems with the formation and function of the heart. It can cause issues with the development of the urinary and reproductive systems. Some people with this condition may have global developmental delays. Some people have minor changes in their facial features and episodes of low blood platelet counts that come and go.

Summary of THOC6-related developmental delay-microcephaly-facial dysmorphism syndrome: THOC6-related developmental delay-microcephaly-facial dysmorphism syndrome is a rare genetic condition. It is characterized by delays in global development. This condition causes mild microcephaly. Microcephaly is a smaller than average head. This condition also casues mild to severe intellectual disability. People with this syndrome may also have non-specific differences to their facial structure. They may have a range of other symptoms present at birth. These include heart defects, dental issues, and malformations of the kidneys and brain. Males may have undescended testicles. Short stature is also common.

Summary of Leukoencephalopathy with mild cerebellar ataxia and white matter edema: Leukoencephalopathy with mild cerebellar ataxia and white matter edema is a rare brain disease. It causes specific differences in the pattern of the brain's white matter. These differences can be seen on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans. People with this disease may experience unsteady movements (mild ataxia). Symptoms include headaches, mild vision problems, and learning difficulties. In some cases, among males, there may be problems with fertility.

Summary of Congenital microcephaly-severe encephalopathy-progressive cerebral atrophy syndr: Congenital microcephaly-severe encephalopathy-progressive cerebral atrophy syndrome is a rare genetic condition that affects the brain. It is characterized by a small head, severe developmental delays, and intellectual disability. This condition causes seizures, and hyperekplexia. Hyperekplexia is an atypical strong and quick reaction to sudden noises or movement. Other symptoms include muscle and movement issues. These include weak muscle tone (axial hypotonia). This can also cause increased muscle tone and stiffness in the arms and legs (appendicular spasticity). Other symptoms include overactive reflexes (hyperreflexia). This condition can also cause uncontrollable movements throughout the body (dyskinetic quadriplegia). This syndrome can also cause vision, feeding, and breathing difficulties.

Summary of Feingold syndrome type 1: Feingold syndrome type 1 is a rare genetic condition that is present at birth. It is characterized by changes in the appearance of the fingers and toes. Symptoms also include microcephaly. Microcephaly is a small head size. Feingold syndrom type 1 can cause minor facial differences. These include small jaw and reduced openings between the upper and lower eyelids. Some people with this condition have problems with the development of the digestive system (gastrointestinal atresia). Mild to moderate learning disabilities may also occur.

Summary of Autosomal recessive spastic paraplegia type 64: Autosomal recessive spastic paraplegia type 64 (SPG64) is a very rare and complex inherited neurological condition. It is characterized by muscle stiffness and weakness in the legs. This is known as spastic paraplegia and can cause difficulty walking. Other symptoms include microcephaly. Microcephaly is a smaller than usual head size. SPG64 also causes muscle wasting (amyotrophy) and problems with coordination and speech. People with this condition may display aggressiveness and delayed puberty. They may have mild to moderate intellectual disability. It is caused by changes in a gene called ENTPD1.

Summary of Tatton-Brown-Rahman syndrome: Tatton-Brown-Rahman syndrome is a rare condition that causes various birth defects. People with this syndrome are often taller than usual. They tend to have mild to moderate intellectual disability, and an atypical facial appearance. This may include a round face, heavy eyebrows, and narrow eyes. Other symptoms may include flexible joints (hypermobile) and decreased muscle tone (hypotonia). This condition can cause a sideways curve of the spine (scoliosis).

Summary of Mucolipidosis type III gamma: Mucolipidosis type III gamma (ML 3 gamma) is a very rare genetic condition. It affects the lysosomes, which play a role in the removal of toxins from the body. It is most commonly seen in the Middle East. This disease is characterized by slow growth in early childhood. It also causes stiffness and pain in the shoulders, hips, and finger joints, and the development of thick or rounded facial features over time. Cognitive function is usually normal or slightly impaired. Gradual vision loss as a result of retinitis pigmentosa (a rare genetic eye disease that affects the retina) has also occurred in some cases. The symptoms of ML 3 gamma progress more slowly than other subtypes of this disease (mucolipidosis type II and type III alpha/beta). Late symptoms may include heart and lung problems that can become life threatening.

Summary of PURA-related severe neonatal hypotonia-seizures-encephalopathy syndrome due to a: PURA-related severe neonatal hypotonia-seizures-encephalopathy syndrome due to a point mutation is a genetic condition present at birth. People with this condition have very low muscle tone when they are born. This can make it hard for them to breathe and eat. Many people with this condition need medical support for these activities. Medical support may include ventilatory support for breathing and feeding tubes for nutrition. They also experience delays in their development and vary in their ability to walk or talk. This condition may also cause seizures, exaggerated startle responses, and other unusual movements. Some people with this condition may have other health issues. These include problems with their heart, urogenital system, skeletal system, or hormones. This condition is caused by mutations in the PURA gene. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. This means a single copy of the mutated gene is enough to cause the disorder.

Summary of Familial porphyria cutanea tarda: Familial porphyria cutanea tarda (F-PCT) is a genetic metabolic disorder. It is caused by a mutation in the UROD gene. This gene is involved in producing heme. The mutation limits how much heme is made and causes porphyrins to build up in the body, especially in the skin and liver. Not everyone with F-PCT develops symptoms. When symptoms do occur, sun exposed skin may be fragile and blister. The skin in the affected area may become infected, scar, grow excess hair, or change color. Symptoms may worsen with alcohol use, certain chemical exposures, viral infections (hepatitis C or HIV), estrogen drugs, and high iron levels. F-PCT is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, meaning that a single copy of the mutated gene is sufficient to cause the disorder.

Summary of X-linked erythropoietic protoporphyria: X-linked erythropoietic protoporphyria (XLEPP) is a rare genetic disorder. It affects the body's ability to handle sunlight. Symptoms usually start in early infancy or childhood. Males with XLEPP experience severe skin symptoms when exposed to light, especially sunlight. These symptoms include tingling, burning, and itching of the skin within minutes of light exposure. Swelling and redness of the skin may also occur. The pain can last for hours or days after light exposure. Some patients may also have liver problems and develop gallstones. Symptoms in females with XLEPP vary, with some displaying severe symptoms while others having few to none.

Summary of 3-methylglutaconic aciduria type 7: 3-Methylglutaconic aciduria type 7 is a rare metabolic condition. It affects the body's ability to break down certain proteins. It can cause a decrease in the number of neutrophils. Neutrophils are a specific kind of white blood cells. Low neutrophils can lead to problems such as frequent and severe infections and the potential to develop leukemia. This condition is also characterized by global developmental delay and intellectual disability. Symptoms include decreased muscle tone, movement difficulties, and seizures. Some people with this condition may also have smaller than usual head size and cataract. They may have atypical facial features, slow growth, hormone imbalances, and/or heart muscle disease. Brain scans may show brain shrinkage, or an atypical formation of the brain region called the basal ganglia.

Summary of NTHL1-related attenuated familial adenomatous polyposis: NTHL1-related attenuated familial adenomatous polyposis (NTHL1-related AFAP), is a genetic condition. It is characterized by an increased risk for developing colorectal cancer and breast cancer. NTHL1-related AFAP also increases risk of multiple polyps or growths in the gastrointestinal tract. Additional cancers reported in people with this condition include endometrial cancer, cervical cancer, and bladder cancer. People may also have cancers of the brain and central nervous system, basal cell carcinoma, and cancers of the blood. Cancers most commonly occur in middle age or later adulthood. NTHL1-related AFAP is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. This means two copies of the mutated gene are required to cause the disease.

Summary of Intellectual disability-macrocephaly-hypotonia-behavioral abnormalities syndrome: Intellectual disability-macrocephaly-hypotonia-behavioral abnormalities syndrome is a rare genetic and neurological condition. This syndrome is characterized by low muscle tone (hypotonia). The condition can also cause global development delay and limited or absent speech. People with this condition may have intellectual disability. People with this syndrome may also have macrocephaly. Macrocephaly is a larger than usual head. This condition can cause atypical facial features. Other symptoms include seizures, and may be on the autism spectrum. In some cases, people may also have problems with their eyes, heart, bones, and central nervous system.

Summary of Microcephaly-corpus callosum hypoplasia-intellectual disability-facial dysmorphi: Microcephaly-corpus callosum hypoplasia-intellectual disability-facial dysmorphism syndrome is a rare genetic condition. It is characterized by varying degrees of developmental delay and intellectual disability. People with this condition may have limited or absent speech, and decreased muscle tone. They may also have a smaller or missing brain region called the corpus callosum. People with this syndrome may also have atypical facial features. These include a long face and a prominent forehead. They may have eyes that are spaced farther apart, downward slanting eyes, and a triangle-shaped upper lip. Other symptoms may include microcephaly. Microcephaly is a smaller than usual head size. This condition can cause seizures and problems with coordination and balance (gait ataxia). People with this condition may have a curved spine (scoliosis), and/or fused fingers.

Summary of Multiple mitochondrial dysfunctions syndrome type 4: Multiple mitochondrial dysfunctions syndrome type 4 is a rare, genetic, neurometabolic disease. It is characterized by the loss of previously acquired skills. People with this syndrome may have vision problems including involuntary eye movements (nystagmus). They may have problems with the white matter portions of the brain (diffuse white matter disease) during infancy. Babies and children with this condition usually have decreased muscle tone. This is due to damage to the central nervous system (central hypotonia). This damage progresses to involuntary muscle contractions (limb spasticity) and overactive reflexes (hyperreflexia). Recurrent chest infections and seizures may also occur. As the disease progresses, multiple regions of the brain can become damaged.

Summary of Facial dysmorphism-developmental delay-behavioral abnormalities syndrome due to: Facial dysmorphism-developmental delay-behavioral abnormalities syndrome due to WAC point mutation is a rare genetic condition. It presents in infancy or early childhood. This syndrome is characterized by global developmental delay. It also causes atypical facial features. These include a broad forehead, a nose with a flat nasal bridge and round tip, and deep-set eyes. This syndrome also affects digestion, sight, and behavior for most people. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. This means that a single copy of the mutated gene is sufficient to cause the disorder.

Summary of SLC39A8-CDG: SLC39A8-CDG is a rare, genetic, metabolic condition that presents during infancy. The condition impairs glycosylation. Glycosylation is the body's ability to attach groups of sugars to proteins. This hinders the proteins from doing important jobs within the body's cells and tissues. As a result, people with SLC39A8-CDG experience a range of symptoms. Symptoms include delayed development, severe intellectual disability, and decreased muscle tone (hypotonia). People with this disease may also experience short stature and asymmetrical head shape. They may have seizures, crossed eyes (strabismus), and recurrent infections. This condition can also cause decreased bone mineral density (osteopenia). Lab results may show low levels of zinc and manganese. Lab results may show atypical patterns of sugar attachment to a protein called transferrin. As this disease progresses, various areas of the brain can shrink (atrophy).

Summary of CLCN4-related X-linked intellectual disability syndrome: CLCN4-related X-linked intellectual disability syndrome is a rare genetic condition. People with this syndrome have a wide range of symptoms. These include epilepsy, intellectual disability, and behavioral differences. Behavioral symptoms include autism, mood disorders, obsessive-compulsive behavior, and aggression. Additionally, people may have continuous worsening of neurological symptoms. These include as problems with movement and muscle stiffness (spasticity). Many females with one copy of the genetic change associated with this condition have few or no symptoms. But, some may be severely affected (similar to males with the condition).

Summary of DDX41-related hematologic malignancy predisposition syndrome: DDX41-related hematologic malignancy predisposition syndrome is a rare inherited condition. It makes people more likely to develop certain types of blood cancers when they are adults. These cancers mainly affect a specific type of blood cell called myeloid cells. The cancers that develop include myelodysplastic syndrome and acute myeloid leukemia. Sometimes people with this syndrome may also develop other immune-related problems. These include sarcoidosis, lupus, asthma, eczema, or juvenile arthritis. They may develop these conditions before or in the absence of developing blood cancer.

Summary of Cerebellar ataxia with neuropathy and bilateral vestibular areflexia syndrome: Cerebellar ataxia with neuropathy and bilateral vestibular areflexia syndrome (CANVAS) is a rare genetic condition. People with CANVAS may experience difficulties with walking (ataxia) and speaking (dysarthria). They may have lack of coordination of their arms and legs. CANVAS can also cause involuntary eye movements (nystagmus). They may have problems with their balance and spatial awareness. People with these symptoms may also have nerve damage. People with CANVAS may also have a chronic cough and/or problems with their autonomic nervous system. The autonomic nervous system is the control center for many body functions. These include blood pressure, heart rate, body temperature, breathing, digestion, and sweating. As this disease progresses, an area of the brain called the cerebellum can shrink (atrophy).

Summary of Stromme syndrome: Stromme syndrome is a rare genetic condition present at birth. It is usually characterized by having a smaller than usual head and smaller than usual eyeballs. People with this condition often have an atypical small intestine that ends in a blockage. Some people with this syndrome may have unusual facial features. These include a narrow or sloped forehead, wide-set eyes, sunken or swollen eyes. The openings between the eyelids may be smaller than usual. Features may include large or low set ears. People with Stromme syndrome may also have a wider nose base and broader nose tip than usual. Features also include a larger than usual space between the nose and upper lip, a small jaw, a thin upper lip, a large mouth, and/or a skin tag on the cheek. Delays in movement and coordination and intellectual disability have also been reported in some people with Stromme syndrome. In some cases, people may experience issues with the heart, brain, and kidneys. Additionally, people with Stromme syndrome may experience swelling in the legs and low levels of platelets in the blood.

Summary of Gabriele-de Vries syndrome: Gabriele-de Vries syndrome is a rare genetic condition present at birth. People with this syndrome may experience delays in their development and intellectual disability. They may also have issues with movement and walking. A variety of atypical facial features may also be present. These may include an asymmetric face, a broad forehead, ears that are rotated towards the back. Features also include a thick lower lip, a small lower jaw, or a split in the roof of the mouth. People with this syndrome might also have problems with their eyes, kidneys, heart, and joints. Some individuals may also present with behavioral differences. These may include being on the autism spectrum, hyperactivity, or anxiety.

Summary of Intellectual disability-seizures-abnormal gait-facial dysmorphism syndrome: Intellectual disability-seizures-abnormal gait-facial dysmorphism syndrome is a rare genetic condition present at birth. It is characterized by global developmental delay and intellectual disability. Symptoms can include seizures, and issues with walking. A variety of atypical facial features may also be present. Features include as a flat nose, angled nostrils, and a nose tip that is wider than usual. Other features include a larger than usual upper jaw and lip, a wide mouth, a more visible gum line, and widely spaced teeth. Some people with this condition may also have eye, heart, or stomach problems, as well as features of autism. People with this disease may also have a thinner brain region called the corpus callosum. They may also have atypical white matter and fluid spaces (ventricles) in the brain.

Summary of Dystonia-parkinsonism-hypermanganesemia syndrome: Dystonia-parkinsonism-hypermanganesemia syndrome is a rare genetic condition. It usually presents in infancy or early childhood. It is progressive which means the symptoms get worse over time. It is characterized by problems with movement. This syndrome is also characterized by high levels of a mineral called manganese in the blood. Symptoms for this syndrome include losing the ability to move, rapidly worsening muscle spasms, and muscle stiffness. They may also have difficulty swallowing and speaking, and symptoms similar to Parkinson's disease. This can make it hard for a person to walk without help. In some cases, thinking and understanding (cognition) may be affected. Other signs of the condition can include an atypical growth of the overall head size. Signs also include changes in the shape of the skull. People may also have atypical formations of various brain regions including the basal ganglia.

Summary of NKX6-2-related autosomal recessive hypomyelinating leukodystrophy: NKX6-2-related autosomal recessive hypomyelinating leukodystrophy is a rare, genetic, neurological disease spectrum. It is progressive, which means the symptoms get worse over time. Some present with symptoms at birth. For them, the disease is characterized by involuntary eye movements (nystagmus). They also have severe difficulty moving and controlling muscles throughout the body (spastic tetraplegia). Those who have symptoms starting at birth may also have problems with sight and hearing. Some start to experience symptoms after the first year. For these people, symptoms may include uncoordinated or jerky movement (spastic ataxia). They may also have a loss of previously acquired developmental skills. These people may have other brain-related problems with coordination, balance, and voluntary movements. People with this condition may have an atypical brain structure. This includes decreased myelin in their white matter. Other brain structure differences include a shrinking cerebellum. There may also be changes to the spinal cord volume.

Summary of Global developmental delay-alopecia-macrocephaly-facial dysmorphism-structural b: Global developmental delay-alopecia-macrocephaly-facial dysmorphism-structural brain anomalies syndrome is a rare genetic condition. It is characterized by global developmental delay, and hair loss (alopecia). This condition also causes a large head (macrocephaly), and an atypical brain structure. People with this condition may have atypical facial features. These include a high and broad forehead. Eye differences include widely spaced eyes and drooping upper eyelids. There may also be a narrowed opening of the eyelids, and sunken eyes. Other features include large ears, and a small jaw or a high arched roof of the mouth. Other possible symptoms include hearing loss, muscle stiffness, and low muscle tone. People with this condition may have small nails, undescended testicles, and curved or bent fingers. Characteristics of the atypical brain structure include atypical white matter. There may also be cysts near the center of the brain. Other brain structure differences include larger than usual fluid filled spaces (ventricles) and/or enlarged spaces around blood vessels.

Summary of Deafness, autosomal dominant 2a: Autosomal dominant deafness 2A (DFNA2A) is a genetic condition that affects hearing. It is characterized by high-frequency hearing loss. This means high-pitched sounds are harder to hear. Over time, the condition causes loss of hearing across all frequencies (low- and high-pitched sounds). The impairment is often detected during routine hearing assessments of children. But, it is likely present from birth. Older people experience moderate hearing loss in lower frequencies. They also experience severe hearing loss in high frequencies. Most individuals with DFNA2A will need hearing aids between the ages of 10 and 40. By the age of 70, they typically have severe to profound hearing impairment. DFNA2A is caused by a mutation in the KCNQ4 gene. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, meaning that a single copy of the mutated gene is sufficient to cause the disorder.

Summary of Epilepsy, familial focal, with variable foci 1: Familial focal epilepsy with variable foci 1 (FFEVF1) is a type of epilepsy that runs in families. This form of epilepsy causes seizures that start in different parts of the brain. People with FFEVF1 often have auras or automatisms during seizures, meaning they may have subjective sensations and experiences or display involuntary repetitive movements. Others have seizures during sleep. Seizures often begin in one area of the brain and spread to other areas. Some people with this condition have abnormal brain waves, intellectual disability, or autism spectrum disorders. Seizures usually start in the first or second decades of life, but they can also occur later. Not everyone in a family with FFEVF1 will have the same symptoms. Some patients have been found to have subtle or clear signs of differences in the cells or structures of the area of the brain known as the cortex. These differences are called focal cortical dysplasia (FCD). FFEVF1 is caused by mutations in the DEPDC5 gene. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, meaning that a single copy of the mutated gene is sufficient to cause the disorder.

Summary of Mitochondrial dna depletion syndrome 2 (myopathic type): Mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome 2 (myopathic type) is a rare genetic disorder that affects the muscles. It is characterized by muscle weakness that usually starts in childhood. People with this syndrome have a decreased amount of mitochondrial DNA in the skeletal muscles. The severity of the condition can vary greatly. Some patients experience symptoms starting in infancy. These patients may experience rapid progression and early death due to respiratory failure. Others have a slower progression and onset of symptoms later in childhood. This syndrome is caused by mutations in the TK2 gene. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. This means two copies of the mutated gene are required to cause the disease.

Summary of Frontotemporal dementia and/or amyotrophic lateral sclerosis 1: Frontotemporal dementia and/or amyotrophic lateral sclerosis 1 (FTDALS1) is a rare neurodegenerative disease. It is caused by changes in the C9ORF72 gene. It can be characterized by frontotemporal dementia (FTD). It can be characterized by amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Or, it can be characterized by a combination of the two. Atypical presentations may also occur. The symptoms of FTD may include progressive changes in personality and behavior. This can include changes in judgement. People with FTDALS1 may have trouble managing thoughts, emotions, and actions. The condition can also cause difficulty communicating. This specific type of FTD also includes neuropsychiatric symptoms like hallucinations and delusions. The symptoms of ALS are mainly related to motor neurons. These include abnormal muscle tone, involuntary rapid muscle twitches, muscle cramps, and trouble walking. Problems with swallowing, speech, and early cognitive impairments can also occur. Symptoms appear during adulthood and may vary significantly between and within families. This causes an unpredictable pattern and age of onset of symptoms. Those with ALS typically present earlier and have more severe symptoms. FTDALS1 is caused by specific changes called hexanucleotide repeat expansions. These expansions occur in the C9ORF72 gene. Hexanucleotide repeats are repeats of 6 specific nucleotides, the basic building blocks of DNA and RNA. When they expand, they increase in size from one generation to the next. Most people have between 2 and 19 repeats. People with FTDALS1 have 250 to over 2,000. Symptoms may occur in people with as few as 20 to 22 repeats. This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. This means most people with this condition inherited the repeat expansion from one of their parents.

Summary of Chromosome xq26.3 duplication syndrome: Chromosome Xq26.3 duplication syndrome is a type of X-linked acrogigantism (XLAG). It is caused by extra genetic material on the X chromosome. This condition is characterized by excessive growth. Overgrowth usually begins during the first year of life in previously normal infants. This overgrowth is caused by the overproduction of growth hormone (GH1). The overproduction is due to pituitary hyperplasia. Pituitary hyperplasia is underdevelopment of the pituitary, and/or a pituitary macroadenoma. Pituitary macroadenoma is is a type of usually benign tumor. Chromosome Xq26.3 duplication syndrome is inherited in an X-linked manner. Most cases represent a single occurrence in a family.

Summary of Hypotonia, infantile, with psychomotor retardation and characteristic facies 2: Infantile hypotonia with psychomotor impairment and characteristic facies 2 (IHPRF2) is a rare neurodevelopmental disorder. Symptoms begin at birth or in early infancy. Children with this condition have decreased muscle tone. They also experience significant delays in their development. These delays may include poor or absent speech and an inability or limited ability to walk. Some may also suffer from seizures. The brain structures of people with this condition typically appear normal. IHPRF2 is caused by mutations in the UNC80 gene. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. This means that two copies of the mutated gene are required to cause the disease.

Summary of Parkinson disease 19a, juvenile-onset: Juvenile-onset Parkinson disease 19A is a rare genetic disorder. It affects the brain and nervous system. It is characterized by the early onset of parkinsonism in the first or second decade of life. Parkinsonism refers to the group of neurological disorders. They have symptoms like stiffness, slow movement, and tremors. Some patients may also experience additional neurological issues. These include developmental delay, intellectual disability, mood disorders, and seizures. This condition is caused by mutations in the DNAJC6 gene. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. This means that two copies of the mutated gene are required to cause the disease.

Summary of Parkinson disease 17: Parkinson disease 17 (PD17) is a genetic movement disorder that affects adults. This type of Parkinson disease is very similar to the more common form of the disease. It is characterized by shaking, slowness of movement, stiffness, and problems with balance. These symptoms tend to be milder. They also present about ten years earlier than those seen in the common form of Parkinson disease. Other symptoms that may occur include problems with thinking and memory, mood changes. PD17 can cause difficulties with the sense of smell and with the body's automatic functions like blood pressure and digestion. PD17 is caused by mutations in the VPS35 gene. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. This means a single copy of the mutated gene is sufficient to cause the disorder.

Summary of Intellectual developmental disorder, autosomal dominant 42: Autosomal dominant intellectual developmental disorder 42 (MRD42) is a genetic neurological condition. People with this disorder experience global developmental delay. This means they have trouble learning new things and developing skills at the same pace as others their age. They also have impaired intellectual development. This can make it difficult for them to learn and function in daily life. Other symptoms include low muscle tone (hypotonia), seizures, and poor overall growth. Symptoms can also include crossed eyes (strabismus), reduced vision, and autistic traits. MRD42 is caused by mutations in the GNB1 gene. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. This means a single copy of the mutated gene is sufficient to cause the disorder. Most cases occur for the first time in a family as the result of a new (de novo) mutation.

Summary of Intellectual developmental disorder with seizures and language delay: Intellectual developmental disorder with seizures and language delay (IDDSELD) is a genetic neurological condition. It is characterized by delays in intellectual and language development during early childhood. It also causes seizures, which are variable in onset and type. People with IDDSELD may also have behavioral differences. Differences include hyperactivity, autism spectrum disorder, anxiety, and sleep disorders. Additionally, some individuals may have different facial features, crossed eyes, or feeding difficulties. IDDSELD is caused by mutations in the SETD1B gene. This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. This means a single copy of the mutated gene is sufficient to cause the disorder. Most cases occur for the first time in a family as the result of a new (de novo) mutation.

Summary of Neurodevelopmental disorder with dysmorphic facies and variable seizures: Neurodevelopmental disorder with dysmorphic facies and variable seizures (NEDDFAS) is a rare genetic neurological condition. It is characterized by global developmental delay and intellectual disability. These symptoms begin in early childhood for people with NEDDFAS. People with this condition may also have seizures and speech delays. NEDDFAS can also cause atypical facial features, and differences in behavior. Additional findings may include mild differences in a personâs bones and kidneys. NEDDFAS is caused by mutations in the EMC10 gene. It is inherited in inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. This means that two copies of the mutated gene are required to cause the disease.

Summary of Melanoma, cutaneous malignant, susceptibility to, 10: Susceptibility to cutaneous malignant melanoma 10 (CMM10) is a genetic condition. This condition is characterized by an increased risk of developing various benign (non-cancerous) and malignant (cancerous) tumors. This includes a type of skin cancer called melanoma. The risk of developing these tumors increases as a person gets older. While tumors typically appear in adulthood, they can sometimes develop during childhood. The types of tumors can affect different parts of the body. This includes the skin, connective tissue, nerves, and blood. Additionally, this condition is characterized by having cells that live longer than usual. This may cause the cells to accumulate changes that potentially lead to cancer. CMM10 is caused by a mutation to the POT1 gene. This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. This means single copy of the mutated gene is sufficient to cause the disorder. Not everyone who inherits the mutated POT1 gene will develop symptoms.

Summary of Parkinson disease 6, autosomal recessive early-onset: Autosomal recessive early-onset Parkinson disease 6 is a genetic condition caused by changes in the PINK1 gene. This condition frequently presents in the early-to-mid-30s. It is characterized by slowly progressive symptoms. These include tremors, slow movement, muscle stiffness, and muscle contractions. Most symptoms are very similar to those seen in other forms of Parkinson's disease. For some people, this condition affects posture, reflexes, behavior, and mental health. As the name suggests, this condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. This means that two copies of the mutated gene are required to cause the disease. A small sub-set of people with this condition have only one mutated gene.

Summary of Dystonia 11, myoclonic: Myoclonic dystonia 11 is also known as myoclonus-dystonia syndrome. It is a genetic condition that affects the muscles. This condition causes sudden, brief muscle jerks. These movements mostly in the proximal muscles near a person's core. Most people with this condition also experience uncontrollable muscle contractions. This can lead to abnormal neck postures (torticollis) or hand cramps (writer's cramp). These symptoms usually start in the first or second decade of life. In some adults, the symptoms may improve when drinking alcohol. Some people with this condition may also develop psychiatric symptoms. These include depression, anxiety, panic attacks, and obsessive-compulsive disorder. Dystonia 11, myoclonic is caused by mutations in the SGCE gene. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. This means a single copy of the mutated gene is sufficient to cause the disorder.

Summary of 2q23.1 microduplication syndrome: 2q23.1 microduplication syndrome is a rare condition caused by an extra piece of genetic material on chromosome 2. It is characterized by global developmental delay and low muscle tone (hypotonia). Symptoms also include autism-like behavior, and other behavioral differences. People with this syndrome may have atypical facial features. These include high eyebrows, wide-set eyes, droopy eyelids, a big nose, a wide mouth, and a small chin. They may also have a friendly personality. In some cases, people may have slight differences in their fingers and toes, like a curved pinky finger and a big, wide first toe.

Summary of Isolated tracheoesophageal fistula: Isolated or H-type tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) is a rare finding in which an abnormal connection exists between the esophagus, or tube that carries food from the mouth to the stomach, and the windpipe, or trachea. Isolated TEF occurs in the absence of esophageal atresia. Isolated or H-type TEF is usually diagnosed in the first few years of life. Early symptoms may include coughing, choking, or a bluish appearance of the skin or lips during feeding. Additional symptoms may include episodes of mild respiratory distress or recurrent pneumonia. H-type TEF may sometimes be associated with other findings such as heart defects.

Summary of Metopic ridging-ptosis-facial dysmorphism syndrome: Metopic ridging-ptosis-facial dysmorphism syndrome is a rare genetic condition present at birth. It is characterized by an abnormal head shape. This can include a prominent ridge on the forehead. There may be varying levels of intellectual disability, and atypical facial features. Features include arched eyebrows, droopy eyelids, slanted eyes, and skin folds in the upper eyelids that cover the inner corner of the eye (epicanthal folds). Features can also include a short, upturned nose. Many individuals with this syndrome experience varying degrees of global developmental delay. Some may be diagnosed with autism. People with this syndrome may also have heart, bone, or urinary system problems. Brain imaging may show partial or complete absence (agenesis) of the corpus callosum.

Summary of Kyphoscoliotic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome due to lysyl hydroxylase 1 deficiency: Kyphoscoliotic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome due to lysyl hydroxylase 1 deficiency is a rare subtype of Kyphoscoliotic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, a genetic connective tissue disorder. It is characterized by reduced muscle tone (hypotonia) present at birth. This condition also causes kyphoscoliosis. Kyphoscoliosis is curvature of the spine. This curvature starts in early childhood and may worsen during the teenage years. It also causes loose and unstable joints that can lead to full or partial dislocations of the shoulders, hips, or knees. People with this syndrome may experience stretchy and fragile skin. The skin is prone to easy bruising and scarring. People may experience weakened medium-sized arteries that may rupture. They may also have lower bone density (osteopenia/osteoporosis). Symptoms also include a blueish tint in the white part of the eyes, small corneas, and/or a hernia near the belly button. Some people may also have a sunken or protruding chest, long and slender fingers, long limbs, clubfoot, and issues with vision. An atypical facial structure is also present for this subtype. This includes low set ears, skin folds in the upper eyelids that cover the inner corner of the eye (epicanthal folds), and a downward slant of the opening between the upper and lower eyelids. Features also include a high arched roof of the mouth. Genetic testing is necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

Summary of Multiple mitochondrial dysfunctions syndrome type 5: Multiple mitochondrial dysfunctions syndrome type 5 (MMDS5) is a rare genetic metabolic disease. It can be potentially life-threatening. MMDS5 affects the brain and nervous system of infants and young children. The condition gets worse over time. It is characterized by seizures, muscle stiffness, and an inability to control muscles. People with MMDS5 also often have issues with their nerves. These include missing or damaged protective nerve coatings called myelin (leukodystrophy). Nerve issues also include having nerves that go to places they typically donât go. Often, people with this disease have too much lactic acid in their blood. MMDS5 is caused by mutations in the ISCA1 gene. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. This means two copies of the mutated gene are required to cause the disease.

Summary of Dystonia 28: Dystonia 28 is a rare genetic disorder that usually starts in infancy or childhood. It is characterized by muscle contractions that get worse over time. The muscle contractions usually begin in the legs and then spread to the arms, torso, face, and neck. People with this disorder experience varying levels of global developmental delay. They also have and intellectual disability that varies from person to person. Additionally, people may have a slightly smaller than usual head size. They may be shorter than usual, and have atypical eye movements. People with Dystonia 28 may have slightly atypical facial features. Dystonia 28 is caused by mutations in the KMT2B. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. This means a single copy of the mutated gene is sufficient to cause the disorder.

Summary of Hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin-intellectual disability syndrome: Hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin-intellectual disability syndrome is a genetic condition present from birth. This syndrome is characterized by slow development of physical and mental skills. This includes affects on walking and coordination. People with this condition may have intellectual disability. They may also have a continued presence of fetal hemoglobin. Hemoglobin is a protein found in red blood cells. Fetal hemoglobin is the main type of hemoglobin that carries oxygen around the body of a developing fetus. It usually disappears in the months after birth. The continued presence of the fetal hemoglobin itself does not cause any symptoms. People with this particular syndrome may have a variety of atypical facial features. These can include a smaller than usual head size, downward slanting eyes, eyes that don't seem to align (strabismus). Features can also include ears that have an atypical shape or structure. This condition is caused by a mutation in the BCL11A gene. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, meaning that a single copy of the mutated gene is sufficient to cause the disorder. Most people with this syndrome have it because of a new mutation (de novo).

Summary of Deafness, autosomal recessive 9: Autosomal recessive deafness 9, also known as DFNB9, is a genetic condition that affects hearing. It is caused by mutations in the otoferlin (OTOF) gene. This condition has two main forms. The first is known as prelingual non-syndromic auditory neuropathy spectrum disorder (ANSD). In the ANSD form, individuals are born with severe-to-profound deafness. They do not have inner-ear abnormalities. ANSD deafness is not usually detected by standard newborn hearing screening. The other form is known as temperature-sensitive auditory neuropathy spectrum disorder (TS-ANSD). Individuals with TS-ANSD typically have normal-to-moderate hearing loss at normal body temperatures. For these people, a slight increase in body temperature can trigger a significant, temporary worsening of hearing. DFNB9 is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. This means that two copies of the mutated gene are required to cause the disease.
